title: teenagers who repaired a vandalised tommy statue in devon are true brits not the grenfell effigy morons
story: If so, three news stories in the past week might suggest Britain is standing just one millimetre away from the clf face of irretrievable, mass inhumanity.Firstly, let’s turn to the pond le who constructed a cardboard model of Grenfell Tower — complete with cut-outs of adults and children in the windows — and set fire to it. One female onlookershrieks, “Help me! Help me!” as the others laugh, while someone  boasts: “I made the burning people.”It’s not just that it’s shockingly distasteful, it’s the sheer callousness of it that renders one almost speechless with disbelief.Then there’s the group of lads in their late teens who thought it funny to spit at Janice Morris as she sat alone on a park bench, before later pelting her with flour and eggs.When police — who class her as vulnerable and with mental health issues — visited her Suffolk home later that day, they found her still covered in flour and with “smudged mascara down her face”.One of the gang — -year-old Cohan Semple — saw fit to take a photo of the attack and posted it on Snapchat.One recipient reposted it to Facebook, it went viral and, quite rightly, prompted widespread revulsion and a police investigation.All five have pleaded guilty to using threatening behaviour which caused harassment, alarm or distress and await sentencing.Meanwhile, it seems “dozens” of the Remembrance Day “Silent Silhouette” statues placed all over the country have been defaced or smashed up by mindless vandals. In Devon alone, one statue was snapped in half, another five vandalised and one stolen.Oh how we wish that,caught in the act, their punishment could be a few weeks on the frontline of a war zone. But don’t hold your breath.Instead, let’s focus on the good in society that, thankfully, still forms the majority. The thousands who expressed their abject disgust at the breathtakingly inhumane bonfire stunt, the horried locals in Bury St Edmunds who helped police locate Miss Morris and bring her tormentors to justice, and the noble volunteers who, seeing the damage to the Silent Silhouette statues, stepped in to repair them in time for this weekend’s Remembrance Sunday.Volunteers such as a group of teenagers in Axminster, Devon, who took a vandalised “Tommy” in to their school workshop and repaired him.Placing him back at the scene afterwards, they laid a wreath and declared: “We are here today to show you that we, as young people, do care.“We care about the sacrices made by the brave men and women who fought for our country.”So let’s take comfort that the true measure of British society lies in their actions and not those of a few morons.“Dry Martini service trolley”, anyone  Nope, me neither.As for the hand-stitched couture Valentino gown, the site describes it as “a dress that defies adjectives”.Oh, I don’t know. “Bloody expensive” comes to mind.MODEL and self-publicist extraordinaire Emily Ratajkowski has published this photo with the caption: “Laundry day.”Cripes. Let’s hope she hits the delicates setting for that T-shirt, as there ain’t too much scope for further shrinkage.Oh dear. Will you tell her or shall I A “CHILD” refugee is under investigation by the Home Office after his fellow pupils at an Ipswich school posted a pic online with the caption: “How’s there a -year-old man in our maths class ”Their suspicions were aroused after finding a Facebook profile in the same name with photos of a man swigging beer while sporting a thick moustache and chest hair. A simple check that took just a few seconds and should have been made by the authorities before they placed him at the school.It seems wily teenagers aren’t anything like as daft as their supposed superiors.The nation clearly needs to get out more.WHILE his estranged we Lisa Armstrong was in court for the initial hearing of their orce, Ant McPartlin was strolling in a park with new love Anne-Marie Corbett and Labrador Hurley.In photos, the canoodling couple appear to be on their own, but in yesterday’s Sun it was reported that, at one stage, “an aide handed Ant a poo bag”. In the interests of clarity, one should perhaps point out the bag was for the dog, not Ant himself. But I digress.The aide’s role reminds me of the old joke about the circus worker whose job it was to clean up prolic amounts of elephant dung.When asked whether he’d ever considered another line of work, he replied: “What – and give up showbiz ”THIS photo of Tom Cruise reprising his role as Maverick for the Top Gun sequel suggests he hasn’t aged at all in the intervening -plus years.Or perhaps it’s simply the wonderfully flattering gravitational pull of a high-speed motorbike.YOU know you’re famous when your No fan is Adele.When she appeared on James Corden’s Carpool karaoke, she was word-perfect on the Spice Girls single Wannabe and said she dreamed of being Ginger Spice.And yesterday, when four of the ladiesannounced a reunion tour, the delightfully down-to-earth Ms Adkins posted a photo of herself, pictured, aged about seven, in front of her bedroom wall papered in their posters and with the caption: “I am ready.”For Adele’s now thirty-something generation, you can’t overestimate the effect of the Spice Girls when they burst on to the pop scene in  with Wannabe.Yes, the “girl power” mantra was a bit cheesy but the point is that for a while they defined the zeitgeist of social change for girls who saw these feisty, opinionated young women having fun primarily on their own terms – and aspired to do the same.They’ve all had their trials and tribulations in the ensuing years . . . but haven’t we all Most of all, the Spice Girls are a mirror of the enduring power of female friendship, with all its twists, turns, complexities, bickering, sniping Mel B and Victoria – who, by the way, are currently speaking and, ultimately, longevity.Welcome back ladies. We’ve missed you.BARONESS Warsi has criticised hit TV series Bodyguard for its “stereotypical” portrayal of Muslim women.“Either she’s downtrodden and needs to be saved or she’s a terrorist and we need to be saved from her,” she says.“In Bodyguard, we think she’s one and she turns out to be the other.”It seems writer Jed Mercurio – criticised by others for being too politically correct – just can’t win.Perhaps he should go back to the drawing board and follow the stereotypes of just about every other crime drama, where the killer always turns out to be a white, middle-aged man.Perhaps they should send a copy to the current crop of largely incompetent candidates on The Apprentice.LOVE Island winners Jack and Dani have moved in together and are reportedly arguing over the smallest things.In other words, the honeymoon period is over and the pair have now moved into the more realistic phase of what is commonly referred to as the long-term relationship.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: how might brexit affect my european holiday everything you need to know
story: But how much will leaving the EU really have an impact on our much-loved European holidays after we go It all depends on whether Britain is able to seal a withdrawal deal with the bloc in the next few weeks.If we can, then things should stay almost exactly the same after we officially leave next March - as we will enter a -month transition period.And after that the real hard work begins on a trade deal and a series of new agreements. Buttheres No Deal, then things could get tricky.Ministers are still working on getting a crucial agreement signed soon, but they could have to implement emergency plans in just days time. What should you know about getting ready for your holidays As part of plans to get ready for No Deal, it was recommended that Brits with less than a year left on their passport get theirs renewed sooner rather than later.Ministers said British people will need to have a passport which is valid for at least six monthsthey want to visit the EU.After we quit the EU our passports will be a navy blue colour, not the current burgundy red.Gloomy Phil Hammond got the nation panicking when he said that under No Deal, planes could be grounded between Britain and the EU. Its a warning thats been repeated by countless politicians since, including the EUs Jean Claude Juncker.Britain would no longer be in the EUs single aviation market, and flights to other countries with which the EU has a deal would also be affected.New agreements can be negotiated, but they could take a while.Airlines are confident that flights will continue to take off regardless - EasyJet and British Airways have said an agreement will be put in place, but Ryanair has been a little more cautious and has begun warning passengers on tickets that it cant be guaranteed.Trains will still run after Brexit, of course. But there are no guarantees that Eurotunnel wont have any disruption next year.As part of a raft of No Deal notices last month, the Government said that companies such as Eurostar, which only holds a UK licence, could be affected unless inidual agreements are struck with the countries it goes to.It advises taking out insurance for Eurostar tickets that cover any Brexit disruption.Under No Deal, UK driving licences would no longer be valid in the EU so holidaymakers would need to buy an international driving permit, available at the Post Office for £..The Government said: You may be turned away at the border or face other enforcement action, for example fines,you don’t have the correct IDP.And you could need a Green card  too - a translation of your car insurance policy - which you can get from the Post Office.But providing ministers secure the -month transition period as planned, this should stay the same.Holidaymakers are delaying booking their ferry crossings for next summer because of Brexit fears, Brittany Ferries said earlier this week, with bookings down  per cent.Dover to Calais and other ferry routes could be impactedchecks have to be made at borders in the event of a No Deal Brexit.But there are unlikely to be any extra delays for tourists, as Brits already get their passports checked en route anyway.No changes should be needed for anyone booking a package deal - unless your booking is with an EU-based firm and made outside the UK, in which case you may not be protected.There was a drop in the pound after Britain voted to leave the EU, meaning Brits will have to stump up more money to get their euros when going abroad on the continent.Buttheres a Brexit deal signed in the next few weeks, the pounds value could increase and make next years a bit cheaper again. A No Deal could see it drop again, pushing up prices.Brits will be able to continue to enjoy free healthcare when travelling in Europe after Brexit, it was confirmed last year.As part of the Withdrawal Agreement, officials have negotiated to use the European Health Insurance Cardacross EU’s  remaining member states – not just the country they’re living in.Pet owners should speak to a vet as soon as possiblethey want to take their animals to Europe after Brexit, Britains top vet warned earlier this week.Brits will need to pay up to £ for the right to take pets on holidaywe leave the EU with No Deal.If we do get a deal in the next few weeks it should be able to continue as normal.Most UK networks say they have no plans to bring back roaming charges after we leave the EU.The bloc scrapped them last year, but there have been fears it could cost more to call and use the internet abroad in future.Ministers have said that any increases again would be limited.Brits could be forced to apply for US-style waivers after Brexit to go on their hols, Theresa May has admitted.Unveiling plans last month to pre-screen EU tourists as part of her new post-Brexit immigration policy, the Prime Minister conceded the arrangements were likely to have to be “reciprocal”.The US currently charges  for every ‘ESTA’ waiver form – raising the prospects Brits will be forced to shell out each time they want to fly to the Costa del Sol.The EU are set to decide within weeks whether the Brits will need a visa in the event of No Deal.

title: bikelife bikestormz army gangs
story: Bikestormz - a collection of thrill-seeking young cyclists up and down Britain - is fighting back with the motto BikesUpKnivesDown.Their intervention couldnt come at a more critical time. This week, a boy of  became Britains th stabbing victim this year - and the nations kne crime epidemic has stretched public faith to breaking point.With police and politicians seemingly at a loss with how to stem the flow of blood on Britains streets, the bike community is desperately trying to prove that you can get a bigger adrenaline rush from cycling than crime.Founded in  by Mac Ferrari, a reformed roadman - a young wannabe gangster - at Bikestormzs last London ride out in August police held up traffic, blocked junctions and even cycled alongside the ,-strong mob in an attempt to limit the chaos.Ferrari, a softly-spoken -year-old explains: I have lost too many people I grew up with to murder to prison, he says.Over nine years I lost  friends to gun and kne crime. My best friend was shot dead in a nightclub when I was standing next to him.Others were sent to jail for all kinds of stuff – murder, robbery, drugs. So I wanted to tell the kids to put the kne down and do something more positive.I was tired of people glamorising the lestyle of crime.I wanted to show them you don’t need to get the adrenaline rush from crime you can get the same buzz from riding your bike. Now Bikestormz is like our church.However, unlike kne-wielding, drug-fuelled gangs that force youngers to break the law to progress up a vicious pecking order, this new obsession is saving lives and keeping kids out of serious trouble, Ferrari claims.Anyone who can peddle hard enough to keep up is welcome – no matter their background. Respect is gained by a rider’s skill and range of cycling tricks, rather than their police record.Authority is established through a series of regular skill events. Fighting is not tolerated. Rude and aggressive behaviour is sanctioned... and already, thousands have been inspired to get off their backsides into the saddle.Incredibly, some riders even say that the bike group has brought peace to London estates which were previously at war with each other.Kizzy, an elite rider, , says Bikestormz has even brought peace to warring South London estates.I used to live in Peckham and there was no way I could go to Brixton without someone attacking me,’ he explains.But when you are on your bike there is no problem.When you are riding no one cares where you are from. We are all together. There is something really positive about  or  of us riding together.’Kizzy, a former Deliveroo rider from south London, says he never carried a kne but lots of kids around him did.When I was young I was a right little s**t – stealing bikes, getting into trouble with the police, bad stuff.But after I got into Bikestormz I wised up. And I know so many people who have put down their knives and got into riding. That’s what it’s all about – doing something positive.Founder Mac had already established a reputation as a stunt motorcycle rider when he got back onto his peddle bike and gained followers for the tricks he posted on Instagram.But he could never have expected to find  young riders raring to go when he organised his first ride out from Tower Bridge – an event now immortalised as Bikestormz.I expected about  kids to come together. When I got there, there were . And I was responsible for them all. It was terrying!I told themthere is any fighting there will not be a Bikestormz. And it all went off peacefully. Now we have grown into a massive family.It gives the kids something to occupy themselves. When they are not riding they are doing up and fixing their bikes.Some kids are rude to drivers and pedestrians when we are out but I tell them to stop it. I don’t put up with road rage.Bikestormz represents the UK version of the bike-riding craze known as #Bikele, which was born in the ghettos of Baltimore and Philadelphia.Now the Bikestormz movement has grown into a nationwide phenomenon with kids pulling wheelies and riding in groups up and down the country whenever they have free time.They gather in large groups in parks and quiet roads in industrial estates at weekends or ride around their local area like a mobile gang. Riders join the pack as they see it roll past.They can also be seen practicing tricks on their own or in groups after school wherever there is space.Riding down stairs – no matter how steep or long – is popular too.Meanwhile, bike trick competitions are held in the parks and waste ground in South London throughout the summer.The top riders are selected to join a select group called Street Elite. They are chosen their skills but also or their responsible attitude.To be selected for Street Elite you’ve got to show a good example to the other riders, explains Montana, an -year-old from Lewisham, south-east London.Bikestormz has been a good influence on me. It has kept me away from trouble.Where I live there is a lot of crime and drugs.But riding is a positive thing. Some days I ride from midday until ten o’clock at night. I love it.I first heard about Bikestormz after it started up. I went to a ride out and I haven’t looked back. It has helped me steer away from crime.Founder Mac and his elite riders attract tens of thousands of Instagram follower and get free bikes, trainers and other merch [merchandise] from sponsors.Kizzy added: Being in Street Elite gives us much more exposure.We get bikes from Mafiabikes, trainers from Nike and we have started music videos for London rappers like JME and Macstar.Wheelie Kay@wheelie_kay .k followersFrom the age of nine I started learning how to wheelie, but it was quite hard, so I left it at that. When I ride with my music it just gives me a lot of energy and people love that.Little Harry@littleharry .k followersAs I got older, around , I started watching loads of dferent people on the internet and realisedI keep on practicing I could be like them one day. For me it’s not a hobby, it’s a lestyle and I love what I do.Jake@jake .k followersI’m  and have been riding since I can remember, I’m filled with adrenaline by wheeling through the tightest gaps and going at high speed through traffic!It’s an amazing feeling being surrounded by hundreds of people how share the same passion as you.Ruby@_rubybailey .k followersI have been riding since [I was] two years old. I’m Street Elite’s first girl rider.Riding has become a massive part of my le and I can definitely see a future in it for me.StreeteliteridersThe London traffic will once again be brought to a standstill by teenagers cycling five abreast when the group go out on their next ride out on Christmas Eve.No one knows exactly how many young men and women will turn up at the Tower Bridge starting line at pm on th December.No route has been planned but the cycle caravan will certainly pass Buckingham Palace, go through Hyde Park, possibly down Oxford and even roll on into the City of London. And no one can stop them.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: coastguard border force patrols dover channel
story: The people, believed to be from Iran, were found on the boat after Border Force and HM Coastguard were called about .am.The Border Force vessel and maritime officers were called, helping the migrants ashore.Those on the boat were given a medical assessment and did not require treatment.They will now be interviewed by immigration officials.A HM Coastguard spokesperson said: HM Coastguard is currently assisting Border Force with an incident in the Dover Channel.Locals reported hearing a helicopter overhead during the incident.It comes after four migrants were stranded on an inflatable dinghy in the middle of the English Channel in September last year.The three men and one woman, aged , ,  and , are thought to be from Iran and were spotted by a fishing boat in the English Channel.

title: toby young creepy tech giants social media
story: In fact, it’s when they are at home that they are most at risk — alone in their bedrooms and in front of a screen.Yesterday The Sun told how the ­Children’s Commissioner for England, Anne Longfield, released some hair-raising statistics about how closely ­children are monitored by the increasingly creepy tech giants.By the time the average British child reaches the age of  they are likely to have posted more than , times on social media, providing companies such as Facebook, Pinterest and Instagram with a treasure trove of valuable ­personal ­information about themselves.But it isn’t just the messages they send to each other.Their day-to-day movements are tracked on their phones and smart watches, their school reports are stored on education databases and their digital medical records are kept by the NHS.It’s asthey’re living in , George Orwell’s dystopian novel about the future, except instead of being monitored by the surveillance state, they’re being spied on by hundreds of Big Brothers.And most of them have not got a clue that it’s happening.Last year, the NSPCC published a report showing that  per cent of young people in the UK have taken a naked or semi-naked picture of themselves, which suggests privacy is not uppermost in their minds.I know from personal experience how dangerous this casual attitude to social media can be.At the beginning of the year, I had to step down from a government job and resign from the boards of several ­charities when some silly things I’d said on Twitter were dug up by my enemies.But eventeenagers were aware just how easily their posts could come back to bite them, they probably wouldn’t ­curtail their online activity because tech companies have become masters of getting people hooked on their sites.Sean Parker, founding president of Facebook, let the cat out of the bag, revealing that social media s deliberately set out to turn people into addicts by exploiting their weaknesses.The reason there are “like” buttons, according to Parker, is because every time a user’s post is liked it creates “a social validation feedback loop”.“We need to give you a little dopamine hit every once in a while, because ­someone liked or commented on a photo or a post or whatever,” he said.We already know just how effective these psychological techniques are when it comes to adults.But our children are so much more vulnerable than us adults.Tech companies such as Instagram, Snapchat and Tumblr are supposed to enforce a minimum user age limit of , but few bother — and research suggests three quarters of ten to -year-olds have a social media account. Should parents be worried  Absolutely, say the experts.The National Crime Agency estimates that about , people in the UK pose a threat of some kind to children online — and the number is rising all the time.It adds there has been a  per cent increase in the referrals it has received about people uploading images of child sexual abuse since .Just as alarming is the damaging effect that smartphones and social media have on children’s mental health.According to Jean Twenge, professor of psychology at San Diego State University, the number of US teens who took their own lives increased by  per cent between  and .And , like me, you have a teenage daughter there is even more reason to be worried.Compared to the early s, nearly twice as many American teenage girls now end their own lives. In the UK, a quarter of -year-old girls experienced signs of depression, according to a study of , young people.Overall, Professor Twenge found that the generation she calls “iGen” — those born after  — are much more likely  to suffer from mental health issues than their millennial predecessors.“What happened that so many more teens, in such a short period of time, would feel depressed, attempt ­suicide and commit suicide ” she asks. “The sudden rise of the smartphone.”If you’re not convinced by the advice of the experts, just look at the behaviour of the people who’ve made their fortunes from peddling this digital crack cocaine.Bill Gates, the billionaire founder of Microsoft, stopped his children from owning a phone until they were  and the late Steve Jobs, co-founder of Apple, would not let his kids play on iPads — even though he invented them.Apple recently introduced a new update that tells you how much time you are spending on your screen each day.That’s a step in the right direction, but don’t expect the company to do too much more. Last year, Apple sold nearly a quarter of a billion iPhones, helping to make it the world’s most valuable brand.The leaders of the tech giants are enriching themselves beyond their ­wildest dreams — not just at our expense but at the expense of our children.So it’s pretty clear they won’t be doing anything to help. And that means that, for now, it’s down to us.We have a choice. We do not have to let our children use their services.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: flu jab shortage over 65s turned away gps
story: Patients have been repeatedly turned away by GPs and chemists.And though fresh supplies should be available next week, there are fears many elderly people will not bother ing.Shortages have been recorded in many areas including Bristol, Kent, Devon, West Sussex, Essex, Derbyshire, Middlesbrough and Liverpool.Sources told the Daily Mail the latest vaccine, called Fluad, is more effective but could not be ordered until later than usual. title: sun says brussels lock uk in forever brexit
story: Diplomats admit to The Sun that the terms of the “Irish backstop” which Theresa May’s Cabinet is poised to back would then be deployed to lock us in its grip permanently.Forget those trade deals with America, China, India, Canada or anywhere .All would be banned.Despite us voting for Brexit. Despite MPs voting to leave the customs union.Despite all the Prime Minister’s ambitious speeches about a global Britain.To get a post-Brexit trade deal, we would have to swallow crippling conditions the EU does not impose on others.Absurdly, it would retain control over the trading policy of the world’s fth largest economy — by then a non-EU member. And, according to Ireland’s cocky PM Leo Varadkar, we would have to stick to all EU rules. Permanently.Can the Tories really sign up to this Or will they stand and fight Some believe we can get out of it all once we have left, next March .We’re not convinced. EvenBritain could, when have we ever done anything but stick slavishly to every letter of our international obligations We are not French, let’s face it.HOW’S this as an excuse for soft justice The Tory “two strikes and you’re out” rule was supposed to mean automatic jail for anyone caught twice with a kne.But hundreds  are still set free by courts ignoring the edict. Now the Tories say “repeat offenders convicted under the ‘two strikes’ rule are  per cent more likely to go to prison than in ”.So it’s “two strikes and you’re slightly more likely to be jailed than before”.No wonder gang members brazenly carry machetes.It’s not just policing that needs radical change — and we welcome Sajid Javid’s claim that signicant new funding is just weeks away.It’s that our courts must get tougher, as a deterrent and to get murderous thugs off the streets.QUELLE surprise! The EU reckons Britain’s economic prospects are worse than those of anyone in its club.And its Remainer stooges pop up like automated bots to carp about their own country being “the sick man of Europe”.That’s the same Europe which has youth unemployment at ,  and . per cent in Spain, Italy and France, compared with our .. And overall unemployment in those countries of ,  and . per cent when ours is four.Of course, the EU’s  forecasters are hardly likely to talk up our prospects.But one thing is clear. Shackle ourselves to their failing model and we’ll fail too.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain poppies remembrance day
story: Respectful Brits in schools, churches and workplaces across the country have spent months preparing beautul arrangements for memorial services on Sunday.The day marks  years since the end of the First World War, which saw more than , brave British military personnel sacrice their lives for the country.The poppy has become a power visual symbol of remembrance for the millions of people today who wear them as a mark of respect.Now weeping widows, made up of thousands of poppies, among other displays have appeared up and down the UK, cascading from church spires and community centres.And school children have worked tirelessly to create handmade memorials to servicemen who gave their lives for Britain.In one particularly poignant display, , poppies were released at BT Groups London headquarters, each one representing inidual postal and telecoms men and women who died in the First World War.Despite the incredible efforts of Brits up and down the land, -year-old war veteran John Geddes warned memories of war are slipping from living history and urged young people to keep the tradition of remembrance alive.The decorated former RAF navigator is among the last of a generation which lived through both global conflicts.During the Second World War he took part in a daring series of enemy raids including the Battle of Berlin, which claimed the lives of more than , British crewmen.John, holder of the DFC , said: With every year the need for remembrance becomes stronger, as the memories slip from living history.Its hard to understand the impact of the war when youve not been involved yourself, but its not something Id ever wish for another generation to encounter.The march from across the military community has been called The Long Walk Home and the journey will finish on Remembrance Sunday at the Cenotaph where the walkers are VIP guests.The walk started in Belgium, then Dover to Canterbury, to Gillingham and then Gravesend to London on Saturday. Friends and family will greet the walkers as theyand join them for the last mile of their pilgrimage.Brigadier James Richardson MBE, chief executive of Haig Housing, said: “The Long Walk Home recognises the great sacrice given by so many in that war and its pilgrimage to walk the route from Flanders to the Cenotaph to take part in the National Act of Remembrance by today’s Veterans will be a poignant commemoration . We hope that the public and in particular the people of Kent give support and encouragement to this event.”All the same, its important that people dont forget just how many people gave their lives, fighting for a better future.Ron was blinded in the war after four years of suffering malnutrition in a Japanese prison of war camp.

title: heres why you should never call your electrician or plumber mate
story: Small talk - including starting with what about the City game last night, eh  - was also singled out by labourers sick of customers trying to make conversation.Clients have also been called out for trying to put on a working class accent while wheeling out the names of random tools as they chat to tradespeople including roofers, plumbers and builders.Mamta Saha, psychologist at Living Potential International, revealed it was all part of the Chameleon Effect - the act of mimicking someone to make themselves or the other person feel more comfortable. But she warned it would wear thin.Ms Saha said: We naturally feel rapport and connected to people who mirror our body language, tone and the essence of words that we use.We have a natural drive to be liked and subconsciously apply a tinge in our accents or an adjustment in our body languagewe feel it is going to bring us closer to someone ‘understanding us’ and as a result they may feel we ‘understand them’ better, bringing us closer and more connected.The main bugbears of builders revealed they were sick of people assuming they were uneducated - while clients forgot to even offer basic acts of kindness like a glass of water.Tarquin Purdie, who is MD at HaMuch –the website behind the study - said it was understandable why people tried to fit in with their builders.He said: Part of this need to adapt your language is down to not wanting to be ripped off.He said even the assumption that builders took three sugars in their tea and that they loved bacon sandwiches had begun to grate.Mr Purdie added: Hopefully this guide will help both sides of the deal.Householders will feel more comfortable and builders won’t have to drink an endless supply of oversweet tea.The Sun saluted plumber James Anderson, who doesnt charge vulnerable customers in desperate need for his help. In little over a year, he’s provided heating and hot water to  vulnerable people throughout Lancashire, where he now lives, by donating his time and expertise entirely for free.

title: teen cyclist head car overtaking bus
story: A dashcam clip shows the young rider weaving across the road before pedalling hard to catch up with a bus.But instead of squeezing past, he started riding towards traffic on the other side of the road and is struck by a black Vauxhall.The smash was caught on camera by grandfather David Alexander, , who was on a school run in York.David had just picked his granddaughter when he noticed the teenage boy dodging traffic moments before the crash.He said he thought the boy was attempting to overtake a school bus and squeeze in between traffic when he had the crash.He said: He was showing a complete disrespect for any other road user. Just before this happened he nearly hit two girls on the pavement.I couldnt believe what I was seeing. Its an example of why cyclists need proper training from an early age.The footage taken in July last year shows the cyclist come flying off his bike and crashing over the cars bonnet.His bike flies into the air and comes clattering down onto the roof of the car.David pulled over after the incident and offered to supply his dash cam footage to the driver of the black Vauxhall involved in the crash.He says he felt sorry for the driver of the car, a man, who was travelling with his we and two children in the car.He said the cyclist dented the cars windscreen and caused some bodywork damage.David added: You could see that he was trying to race the bus. When I went over after it happened he was staggering around and was dazed.He kept saying hes sorry. Ive got no idea how he managed it. He cant have been looking ahead of him.

title: brits need four hours extra in the day to get everything done do you agree
story: Long hours at work, household chores and looking after the children means people are struggling to tick off the to-do list.According to a poll of , adults,  hours in a day would give them time to actually enjoy their days and get more sleep.Over half of the people surveyed also said that they would like more time to have fun, with six in  saying that they cant recall the last time they had a spare  minutes to do something they really wanted to do.National Geographic have found that on Mars the days are  minutes longer than here on planet earth.And thats unlikely to change anytime soon, but on Mars its a dferent story - a day is  minutes longer than on Earth.Readers might be wondering what good is that is to them, but as our new show MARS reveals, Earthlings could be living on the Red Planet in the not too distant future.As well as sleeping, people said that they would like more me time or time to get into a good book.And perhaps this is because much of the population is exhausted from work - a fth of those polled said they are hindered by an uneven work   le balance.The survey was commissioned to celebrate the second season of MARS which premieres on National Geographic this Sundayat pm.

title: brexit theresa may deal brussels
story: Leave-backers say they will block the PMs agreement no matter what she brings back from Brussels.Former minister Steve Baker said that it was not really about the backstop and insisted the whole thing was unacceptable and didnt deliver on the referendum result.Mrs May is still in the final stages of crunch talks with the bloc about the back-up plans for Northern Ireland - in case no agreement is secured for a future trade deal.The PM is hoping to win over her Cabinet ministers and seal a deal with the EU in the next week - even though she was hit with the resignation of another minister today, Jo Johnson.But Mr Baker said yesterday that Brexiteers would still throw it out.He said: In the end, it’s not really about the backstop,” he said. “The tearing frustration is that the UK has been negotiating with itself.Many of us have long believed that the row over the backstop is at least partly confected in order to have an orchestrated breakthrough.That sets up Mrs May up for a Commons showdown in the coming weeks, as she pleads with MPs to back her deal or threaten them with No Deal at all.Meanwhile, Mrs Mays government allies, the DUP, are furious with her today as they believe shes set to cut them off from the rest of the UKtheres no Brexit agreement.The PMs  partners accused her of betrayal and breaking promises over the Northern Irish border in a letter she wrote to them earlier this week.DUP boss Arlene Foster said today that the note, revealed in The Times, raises alarm bells for those who value the integrity of our precious union and for those who want a proper Brexit for the whole UK.She thinks the letter means the Prime Minister is wedded to creating a border down the Irish sea in the event Britain cant secure a long-term trade deal with the EU, which would then leave Northern Ireland stuck in the EUs regulatory regime.

The Shadow Home Secretary – one of Jeremy Corbyn’s closest allies - said her “suspicion” is that Brits would Brexit all over again at the polls.Speaking on Question Time last night, she said: “I will say this about the second Referendum. You should be careful what you wish for.“If we had a second referendum now the same people who voted leave last time, who are not largely speaking in London, would vote leave again saying: ‘Didn’t youThe comments came just days after Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer reiterated that Labour could back a second Referendum.At Labour Party conference, he said the option of remaining in the EU would be an option on the table.The news came just hours before Jeremy Corbyn told German paper Die Speigel: We cant stop Brexit.He said when quizzed over the issue: The referendum took place. Article  has been triggered. What we can do is recognise the reasons why people voted Leave.Lots of people were angry about the way they had been left behind, he insisted.The Labour boss was also asked about whether he felt sorry for the PM.He replied, hinting she should quit and let Labour take over: I am a decent human being, I feel sorry for anyone in distress. But the best way for anyone to alleviate distress is to take yourself away from the source of it.Business leaders including former BT chair Sir Mike Rake and ex-Sainsbury’s boss Justin King on Thursday called for a second Referendum.The former Sainsbury’s chief said the current choice facing the British public was a “bad Brexit or a disastrous Brexit”.And today Boris brother Jo quit over Brexit too - and also demanded another vote to check whether Leaving was still what the people wanted.

title: when is equal pay day 2018 what does it mean and why are women setting their out of office up
story: Heres what you need to know about Equal Pay Day.Equal Pay Day is essentially when women work for free until the end of the year.This symbolic day is dedicated to raising awareness of the gender pay gap.This year, Equal Pay Day in the UK falls on November .The . per cent figure is calculated by the Fawcett Society using ONS gender pay gap statistics.Earlier this year, gender pay gap reporting regulations meant that companies with more than  employees had to publish figures showing any dferences in pay between men and women.Of those that published data,  per cent pay men more than women,  per cent pay women more and  per cent said they had no gender pay gap.The Fawcett Society is trying to encourage UK workers to talk more openly about their salaries, in a bid to bring an end to pay inequality.Sam Smethers, Fawcett Society chief executive, said: “In workplaces all over the country, pay discrimination is able to thrive and is more common than people realise because of a culture of pay secrecy which persists. People do not know their basic rights and do not know what their colleagues earn.”This year, to help women fight back against gender pay gaps the Fawcett Society has teamed up with employment law charity YESS Law to launch a new Equal Pay Advice Service, paid for by an Equal Pay Fund.In , the Out of Office campaign reached over . billion people, calling for real action on the gender pay gap.Some women would not come into work on Equal Pay Day to prove a point to their employers.Others would set up the notication which said the recipient is in the office, but gave an automatic alert to senders that it’s Equal Pay Day and raises awareness.Many women will be making a point to ask their colleagues what they earn in an effort to improve transparency.Others will be taking to social media to share an equals sign, or post with the #GetEqual and #EqualPayDay tags. Catherine Mayer, co-founder of the Womens Equality Party, tweeted: Ive switched on my #OutofOffice for the rest of   my Twitter isnt working either.Why  Because the #genderpaygap means this is the last day until Jan UK women get paid to work relative to men. The gap is greater for BAME  disabled women.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lenny henry arts vital for a childs sense of inclusion
story: And good people are saying good and sensible things about children and the arts - it just feels like no one really cares. And the problem is that the creative arts are a huge boost to the GDP of Great Britain.In January, thesaid the creative industries were "worth #bn to the UK economy"."The sector s more golden eggs to the Treasury than the automotive, oil, gas, aerospace and le science industries combined, and for every # invested in subsidy the government gets # ed in taxes."So why is the government cutting back on the creative arts in schools  Why this insistence on STEM , this rejection of the arts The truth is, this was always going to happen. When I was at Blue Coat secondary modern there was little or no attempt to cultivate dramatic aspirations during the school day. Sure, we were tasked with reading aloud or taking part in an assembly we even did a school concert the year I had successfully auditioned for New Faces. But the only drama I remember taking part in was when Mr Kipperwould have us in the hall for a double period and make us run around pretending to be characters we had seen on television or at the pictures.When we were kids, there were not many chances to pop into a performance of Hedda Gabler or the Dolls House. The fact is, theatre didnt play a massive part in my parents lives. They spent every hour God gave putting food on the table and clothes on our backs. They were not also going to pop us in for a matinee of She Stoops To Conquer at the Wolverhampton Civic. They werent made of money. So, no theatre.

title: ww1 pictures powerful images show
story: WW pictures: Powerful images show full horror of le in the trenchesPowerful images from the Daily Mirror archives chronicle the story of WW from the beginning until Armistice Day with astonishing moments of the conflict capturedShareCommentsByBradley JollyDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe full horror of le in the trenches has been uncovered in an incredible set of historic photographs capturing the daily threat of bullets and silent gas attacks. Images uncovered from Daily Mirror archives capture the essence of the First World War, with gunfire, people scrambling to get on rescue boats and other daily threats soldiers faced. Scenes of conflict are contrasted poignantly with everyday moments  - making a cup of tea, having a joke, and reading the paper. A conflict of this scale had never before been documented in such striking visual detail.Photographers for the world’s first picture paper - The Daily Mirror -  travelled from Belgium and into France, through Poland to Russia, the Middle East and Gallipoli to tell the story of the war to readers back home.This astonishing image shows a huge number of soldiers from the South Stafford and North Stafford Regiments. They crossed the St Quentin Canal which was part of the Hindenburg line, a German defensive position, in lebelts. The photo captures one of two bridges which allowed guns to be taken across the canal. of British troops asleep on Boulogne Quay, having just arrived to join their French and Belgian Allies of The drama of the conflict is captured in this image as a British boat is torpedoed and the crew scramble to get onto leboats. Moments between le and death such as this were caught in the striking photography.  of Ernest Brooks snapped this six-inch heavy gun firing on the Western Front during the build up to the Battle of Somme in June . Smoke can be seen billowing in the background as soldiers stand nearby.  of Soldiers from the Kings Liverpool Regiment are pictured huddling around to listen to the news being read out in their trench, a moment of apparent normality amid the brutal war.  of One of the myriad of Star shells is pictured bursting at night, spreading sparks into the pitch black sky near the British lines on the Somme.  of British cavalry are seen crossing a temporary bridge over the Somme in this striking image, among the collection published by the first picture paper The Daily Mirror.  of George Mewes, who was Official Photographer to the Russian Army, captures an image of Russian Emperor Tsar Nicholas II looking through a periscope at the enemy position on the front line of the Eastern front.  of This scene shows King George V describing an amusing incident to King Albert I of the Belgiums as they walk side by side.  of The silhouette of a soldier preparing his morning tea - another glimpse of a mundane daily task contrasted with the horror of the war.  of Soldiers removing shells from an underground store on the Western Front in France in April , with one leaning over a huge gun.  of Canadian troops are seen here advancing over no mans land and through the German barbed wire whilst under fire.  of Ivor Castle, another British photographer, documents railway stations at which crowds of refugees carry spare clothes and loaves of bread, snatched in haste.  of Bristol-born Ivor Castle took the first picture of a British tank, for which The Mirror paid the War Office pound,.  of The Royal Marines stand guard over the Dardanelles, the narrow strait that forms part of the border of Europe and Asia.  of A soldier drives a horse and supply cart through water logged fields and roads in muddy Flanders Fields, the battlefields that straddle parts of Belgium and France.  of French soldiers charge across a field with rles raised in another remarkable shot of the conflict.  of Here Belgian troops are pictured defending a road leading to Fort Waelham, Antwerp, from a German attack.  of Each image, including this of the company of the th Regiment of Chasseurs, was sent to the Petrograd Soviet in Russia and then sent by courier to the UK.  of From the first day of conflict to the very last, press photographers from the UK would travel to Belgium and France to picture our troops. Here, a sergeant of the Lancashire Fusiliers is seen posing in a flooded trench.  of Photographers documented their visions of the war and horrors of the trenches in The Daily Mirror. of More OnWorld War ICommentsShow more comments

title: 25 ww1 facts figures show
story: News WW facts and figures that show the reality of the conflict ahead of centenaryWorld War One in facts and figures from when it began and why to weapons and plastic surgeryShareCommentsByJo-Anne RowneyAudience Growth Editor:,  NOV News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen you think of World War One images of bloody warfare, dirty trenches and explosions may come to mind, but theres more to the reality of the war than thar. While it may capture some of the reality of what happened on the Front Line, the political reasons and mundane day-to-day le in the trenches is often forgotten. What about the post that was sent, the women who helped and the impact the war had - from pioneering plastic surgery to blood banks. Here are  facts about World War One that tell the story of what really happened.. When did WW begin  WW began on July ,  . Why did World War One start  It all began because of the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria. He was heir to the throne of Austria-Hungary. . Who were the two sides  The Triples Ententes - also known as The Allies, were the British, France, Ireland and Russia. The other side are known as The Central Powers, Germany and Austria-Hungary. . Did Italy change sides  Italy were originally on The Central Powers side, part of a Triple Alliance. They left the alliance when it was clear it was offensive rather than defensive. Italy left and joined The Triple Ententes and declared war on Austria-Hungary in May,  and Germany in August, . . World War One has many names The Great War, the World War, the War to End all Wars, World War , WW, and the War of the Nations are just a few.  . How many soldiers died  More than eight million soldiers died in WW, and another  million were injured. If youre wondering how many soldiers were mobilised, there were  million. . When did America join WW  April , . A German submarine sunk a British passenger ship called the Lusitania, killing , passengers -  of which were American. The US was outraged and pressured their government to declare war. Woodrow Wilson, the president at the time, wanted a peaceful route but the Germans said any ship that came near Britain would be sunk. Wilson agreed to enter the war to bring a peaceful end. They were only in combat for seven months, but around , soldiers were killed and , were injured. . Chemical weapons were first used in WW Poison gas was seen as war crime, but using tear gas wasnt seen in the same way. The Germans first used the lethal gas in a chlorine. . The German strike The Germans werent always on board with the war. In , the German citizens began striking and demonstrating against the war. They were starving, and their economy was collapsing as the ports were blocked.  . When did WW end  June ,  - five years after the assassination of Franz Ferdinand. The armistice on November ,  ended the fighting, but it took another six months to negotiate peace before the Treaty of Versailles was prepared. . What was the Treaty of Versailles  It was basically an agreement to agree to the end of the war, and peace. The Germans had to accept full responsibility for causing the war, and there were consequences for this. The Germans had to surrender some of its territories and colonies and limit the size of its military. . What was the League of Nations  It was formed to prevent future wars. Germans resented the conditions in the Treaty of Versailles, and Germany and Japan eventually withdrew from the LoN in . Italy withdrew in . In the end the LoN couldnt stop Germany, Italy or Japan expanding their power. They took over smaller countries, and many think this is why WW never really ended, but continued with WW. . How many survived  Nine out of  British soldiers survived in WW. . What did they do in the trenches  British soldiers were moved around the trench system and werent often in the direct firing line. It wouldve been boring in between, with soldiers carrying out routine jobs and duties. . Army generals were banned from going over the top So many wanted to fight they were actually banned from fighting. If they were killed then the experience they had would be lost.  . There was a blood bank When soldiers were injured they gave them blood transfusions - transferring blood from one soldier to another. US Army doctor Captain Oswald Johnson set up a blood bank on the Western Front in . Blood was kept on ice for up to  days using sodium citrate to prevent it from coagulating and becoming unusable. . How old was the youngest soldier  Just  years old. He was called Sidney Lewis. He lied about his age to get into the army. He was one of , underage soldiers. . Plastic surgery came about in WW Surgeon Harold Gillies helped shrapnel victims who had terrible facial injuries with plastic surgeries. Its one of the earliest examples. The metal caused horrible injuries that were worse than the straight bullets. .  million letters were delivered  million letters were delivered to the Front every week. It took two days to send a letter from Britain to France. A mail office was set up in Regents Park, London to send letters to the trenches.  billion letters and  million parcels were sent during the war. . An explosion in France was heard in London A group of miners dug tunnels up to ft underground, to plant and detonate mines behind enemy trenches. The biggest success with it was at Messines Ridge, Belgium, where over ,lbs of explosives were detonated at one of the  tunnels underground. A lot of the German front line was destroyed, and the blast was so big it was heard up to  miles way - even the British Prime Minster heard it in Downing Street.  . Journalists risked their lives Journalists risked their lives to report on the reality on the front line. The Government began to try and control what information got back from the trenches, and journalists were banned. If you reported on the conflict you were seen as essentially helping the enemy. If caught, you could even face the death penalty. . Wilfred Owen was unknown before the War Hes now one of the best known poets of WW, but when he died on the front line - a week before the war ended - he was still unknown. The way his words painted the imagery of war, one of pity, horror and terror, was actually a minority view. In the s a literary elite decided his poetry was a more authentic view and two key war poetry war anthologies were published featuring him heavily. WW pictures: Powerful images show full horror of le in the trenches . Womens skin turned yellow As the men headed off to war, women took their place. More than a million women joined the workforce. They worked in poor conditions with dangerous chemicals and long hours. They were often called canaries as when they worked with TNT they got toxic jaundice - their skin turned yellow. . WW nearly caused financial meltdown Britain was an economic superpower, but the war cost more than any ever before. Bullets fired in one  hour period in September  was nearly four million pounds. . WW ship camouflage Merchant ships had to be protected so Norman Wilkinson, an artist and Royal Navy volunteer, came up with the idea of covering ships in bold shapes and contrasting colours. It was nothing like camouflage people had seen before and it was more meant to confuse than conceal.

title: how cook roast dinner sunday
story: AdvertorialHow to cook the perfect roast dinner…when you have more than  people to feedExpert chefs from Toby Carvery and The Royal Navy join forces in the kitchenShareByDave Masters:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Advertorialthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video toby-carvery-royal-navy-join-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAnybody who has ever cooked a Sunday roast will tell you what a juggling act it can be getting your food out on time. So imagine how tough it can be when youre serving  roast dinners in each of your restaurants every week and not just the extended family. Thats the task faced every week by the expert chefs of The Toby Carvery. Millions of families sit down to tuck into a delicious roast dinner every week - wherever they are in the world. So ahead of Remembrance Sunday - and in a bid to help readers who tackle the job of cooking the Sunday roast each week - weve brought The Toby Carvery together with the chefs of The Royal Navy to get their top tips in the above video. Toby Carvery - the Home of the Roast - has long been a supporter of the armed forces, offering free meals to troops on Armed Forces Day.  And in the above behind-the-scenes clip on board HMS Northumberland, Toby Carvery Chef Trainer James Smith joins forces with the Royal Navys Chef Mitchell to lt the lid on how best to cook meats, roast potatoes, Yorkshire puddings and even gravy. Toby Carvery Chef James hails The Royal Navy for creating that home-from-home roast dinner experience at sea in the clip, saying: For many families, roast dinners are that one time everybody gets around that dining table. A really good roast dinner is just like having a really big hug on a plate!  Meanwhile, The Royal Navys chef Mitchell explains how important the traditional meal is to troops across the world. He adds: Ive cooked for Royalty and some of the biggest dignitaries of the Armed Forces, but every Sunday - guaranteed - ships across the world are having a roast dinner. Below, weve shared the top tips from the guys on the key ingredients to help families across the country cooking up a roast. Meats  Toby Carverys Chef James says: One of the tricks we use at Toby is to bloom our meat for a minimum of four hours first of all. So we take them out of the packaging and that lets the joints re-oxigise. We then load them into ovens and cook them really slowly. Letting them rest at the end is a key step to getting perfect beef. Yorkshire puddings  Were famous for our seven centimetre Yorkshire Puddings at Toby Carvery, reveals chef James. The trick to Yorkshires is making sure youve got really hot oil. Then add your batter to the oil and get them in the oven as quickly as you can. Roast potatoes Its all about the ruffling, chef James says, shaking a tray of uncooked but peeled and chopped spuds.  You want to shake them up and make sure you break the edges of the potatoes up. Then that will give us a really nice, crisp roast potato. Gravy  Chef James says: Theres nothing worse than thin or lumpy gravy! Consider adding cranberry sauce, mustard or horseradish. Meanwhile, The Royal Navys Chef Mitchell adds: We always go for a nice smooth, thick gravy. We normally put in a bit of red wine to give it a dferent taste. Ive even put Marmite in!Find your nearest Toby Carvery at www.tobycarvery

title: jealous girlfriend drove partners ex
story: NewsJealous girlfriend drove partners ex to suicide bid by sharing intimate snaps of herRachel Dale, , discovered graphic pictures of the victim on her partners phone and shared them with her , Instagram followers, a court heardShareByAmy Walker:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsRachel Dale posted the explicit pictures on Instagram "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA jealous girlfriend drove her partners ex to a suicide bid after she shared explicit photos of her on Instagram. Rachel Dale, , from Tameside, Greater Manchester, discovered the graphic images on her partner’s phone on her birthday. She warned the victim they would be all over the Internet tomorrow before sharing them with her , Instagram followers. The pictures were deleted after eight minutes but had already been circulated on social media forums and ious online chatrooms. The unnamed victim was so devastated by the disclosure she tried to take her own le, reports the Manchester Evening News. She was treated in hospital before being allowed home.  At Tameside Magistrates Court in Greater Manchester, Dale, of Stalybridge wept as she admitted an offence of disclosing a private sexual photograph with intent to cause distress under ‘Revenge Porn laws.’ But she walked free with a suspended jail term after she claimed the offence occurred after she had been made redundant from another clothing firm where she had been a retail buyer. The court heard that Dales boyfriend had a brief relationship with the victim - several years ago, before he met Dale - and that she sent ious explicit pictures of herself to him. The woman had asked him to delete the images just a day after she sent them but the court heard the explicit pictures remained on his phone.  Prosecutor Ashley Seetal told JPs: “In October this year the defendant finds these pictures of the victim onphone before uploading them to Instagram, a popular social media site. “The Instagram account which the images were uploaded on was a joint Instagram account used by the defendant and . This had been set up and was used to promote the business which they worked together on. “The account had , followers. These pictures were uploaded and made public, this means that the images can be seen by all , followers. “Prior to uploading the images to Instagram, the defendant sent the victim a message and in that message she alluded to posting the pictures online and in one message she said: ‘They will be all over the Internet tomorrow.’  “The images being uploaded of a graphic and intimate area, were shared to a number of group chats and social media chats. “The victim did attempt to take her own le, this was a serious attempt and she was taken to hospital and received treatment. The images when posted onto Instagram, the popular social media site, were viewable to a number of followers and the wider public. There is evidence of serious distress and serious signicant psychological harm.” A probation report read to the court said Dale ‘accepts full responsibility’ and has ‘saidshe could turn back the clock she would.’She claimed to have been suffering from anxiety at the time - having been made redundant days earlier.  “She has been in this relationship for two and a half years. She says the relationship is good but she does have some concerns about the status of the relationship,” the report said. “She was working full time and working with her partner on the side on their own business, which she invested in financially, as well as investing her own time and effort. “She has not told her family in fear of their reaction. She has got a stable lestyle. She has concerns, she is not surethe relationship will continue long term. She still has to work things out with the business. “She is not sure how successful it is going to be. Whilst the victim had slept with her boyfriend, this hadn’t previously played on the mind of the defendant and the two parties have little to do with each other and were at an amicable level.  “But she went out celebrating the night before as it was her birthday and on finding the photo on the phone, she says she acted on impulse with intent of seeking revenge. She said she was quite distressed and said ‘there were no other options at the time.’ In mitigation, Dale’s defence lawyer Gavin Clarke said: “This is a lady who on October  this year was in a relationship with her partner for two and a half years. “They have a shared account due to their business together. At .am she has been awoken by a number of images sent from a third party, from the victim, sent to her partner at the time. “She sees these images, graphic and explicit images and she is devastated, she is mortied. She then texts the victim and pre warns her. Yes, she does upload those to an Instagram profile.  They are up there for - minutes. They are not up there for eight months, they are not put on a streaming site. “They are uploaded to an Instagram account with between , to , followers. It was posted for between  and  minutes at . in the morning. In terms of how many people who have viewed those, the numbers are going to be extremely limited. “The person who followed the account would have to be on that account at that time. They would have to be looking at that particular account. There is no preplanning, this is a spur of the moment. This young lady, as soon as she calmed down, she realised the error of her way and took it down, that’s the end of the story. “I accept there has been some humiliation but this is very dferent to revenge, this was a spur of the moment. She was going about her own business, finds this on her partners phone and reacts there and then. This was not out of revenge or some kind of hatred.  “This is a young lady of , who has never appeared before the courts before and I dare to say I don’t think she is ever likely to came back to this court again. This offence is something she genuinely regrets. Dale was sentenced to  weeks jail suspended for a year and was ordered to pay pound in costs and surcharges. She did not comment after the hearing. story: NewsPupils and staff unwell after pepper spray let off inside Manchester schoolA spokeswoman for Greater Manchester Police said it is believed pepper spray was brought into Manchester Health Academy by a studentShareCommentsByLuke AndrewsAlexandra Rucki:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe incident at the Manchester Health Academy happened on Friday morning"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA number of students and staff were taken ill after what is believed to be pepper spray was let off in a high school. A spokeswoman for Greater Manchester Police said it is believed pepper spray was brought into the school in Wythenshawe by a student. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Crews were also seen parked up outside the school building, also known as Brookway High School, just before am. This incident has been dealt with by Mr Green. All students are safe. If the spray has caused a reaction for your child, you will have been notied separately. We will continue to monitor students throughout the day.  Kevin Green, school principle, said: We have sent a text to all parents to reassure them and let them know all our pupils are safe. An aerosol was sprayed in a corridor after morning registration around am to .am. I have been here for five years and I have never seen a single case of this. The children and staff who were affected presented with watery eyes and feeling unwell. One pupil is being spoken to by police. It is up to them what to do now. We will impose our own punishment.
